articles.headline: Approval for Drug That Treats Melanoma
articles.snippet: Yervoy, made by Bristol-Myers Squibb, is the first drug shown to prolong the lives of people with the skin cancer melanoma.
articles.abstract: Yervoy, made by Bristol-Myers Squibb, is the first drug shown to prolong the lives of people with the skin cancer melanoma.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first drug shown to prolong the lives of people with the skin cancer melanoma won approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Friday.

articles.headline: Insurance Dictated by the Bank
articles.snippet: The practice of bank-imposed insurance — known as force-placed insurance — has become more widespread in parts of the country where foreclosures are prevalent.
articles.abstract: The practice of bank-imposed insurance — known as force-placed insurance — has become more widespread in parts of the country where foreclosures are prevalent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Back in November, my bank sent my wife and me a letter asking that we provide proof of flood insurance for the condominium we own in Florida. We did. But three months later, we found ourselves in the midst of a Kafkaesque world, where we were being charged for bank-imposed insurance and couldn’t figure out a way to get the bank to take back the insurance and remove the charges.

articles.headline: If the Taxes Are Done, You Might Consider a Financial Tuneup
articles.snippet: After you’ve sent off your return, think about taking a fiscal health day and knocking items off your financial to-do list. Here are some suggestions.
articles.abstract: After you’ve sent off your return, think about taking a fiscal health day and knocking items off your financial to-do list. Here are some suggestions.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s hard to find many people who derive much joy from income tax season. But consider for a moment what you end up with.

articles.headline: Less Appetite for Luxury
articles.snippet: Analysts say the triple disaster has jolted the Japanese, who last year consumed more luxury goods than any single region, into a new reality based on helping others.
articles.abstract: Analysts say the triple disaster has jolted the Japanese, who last year consumed more luxury goods than any single region, into a new reality based on helping others.
articles.lead_paragraph: At age 23, Maki Kusaka, an office worker in Tokyo, has 10 Gucci handbags lining her wardrobe, the fruits of an obsession she has shared with countless other Japanese to collect the world’s hottest luxury brands.

articles.headline: Newly Homeless in Japan Re-Establish Order Amid Chaos
articles.snippet: At an evacuee center in a town ravaged by the tsunami, residents lose no time re-establishing the efficiency characteristic of Japanese life.
articles.abstract: At an evacuee center in a town ravaged by the tsunami, residents lose no time re-establishing the efficiency characteristic of Japanese life.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIKUZENTAKATA, Japan — Koji Yamaguchi, a 76-year-old survivor of the tsunami that all but eradicated this town on March 11, was unavailable for interviews. He was out walking his dog.

articles.headline: In Prison for Taking a Liar Loan
articles.snippet: The government did send someone to prison for actions related to the subprime mess. But not who you’d expect.
articles.abstract: The government did send someone to prison for actions related to the subprime mess. But not who you’d expect.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, when the Justice Department decided not to prosecute Angelo Mozilo, the former chief executive of Countrywide, I wrote a column lamenting the fact that none of the big fish were likely to go to prison for their roles in the financial crisis.

articles.headline: Budget Impasse Increasing Risk of U.S. Shutdown
articles.snippet: Congressional leaders are growing increasingly pessimistic about reaching a bipartisan deal that would avert a government shutdown in early April.
articles.abstract: Congressional leaders are growing increasingly pessimistic about reaching a bipartisan deal that would avert a government shutdown in early April.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With time running short and budget negotiations this week having reached an angry impasse, Congressional leaders are growing increasingly pessimistic about reaching a bipartisan deal that would avert a government shutdown in early April.

articles.headline: Global Supply Lines at Risk as Shipping Lines Shun Japan
articles.snippet: Japan’s busiest ports in Tokyo and Yokohama are being avoided by global shipping lines fearful of radiation contamination.
articles.abstract: Japan’s busiest ports in Tokyo and Yokohama are being avoided by global shipping lines fearful of radiation contamination.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The economic disruptions from Japan’s crisis have cascaded into another, crucial link in the global supply chain: cargo shipping.

articles.headline: Silicon Valley Hiring Perks: Meals, iPads and a Cubicle for Spot
articles.snippet: Companies, particularly start-ups, are offering an array of perks — including lessons in entrepreneurship — to lure whiz kid engineers.
articles.abstract: Companies, particularly start-ups, are offering an array of perks — including lessons in entrepreneurship — to lure whiz kid engineers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Eric Firestone began a new job at a Web start-up here three weeks ago, and he’s already thinking about what he might do next. But that’s just fine with his new employer.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Jenna Wortham

articles.headline: It’s Tracking Your Every Move and You May Not Even Know
articles.snippet: A German politician was surprised to learn he was being tracked by his cellphone carrier.
articles.abstract: A German politician was surprised to learn he was being tracked by his cellphone carrier.
articles.lead_paragraph: A favorite pastime of Internet users is to share their location: services like Google Latitude can inform friends when you are nearby; another, Foursquare, has turned reporting these updates into a game.

articles.headline: Airstrikes Clear Way for Libyan Rebels’ First Major Advance
articles.snippet: As night fell, rebel forces had driven almost uncontested to the town of Brega, erasing weeks of losses as airstrikes opened the way.
articles.abstract: As night fell, rebel forces had driven almost uncontested to the town of Brega, erasing weeks of losses as airstrikes opened the way.
articles.lead_paragraph: AJDABIYA, Libya — Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s forces retreated from this strategic city on Saturday, running for dozens of miles back along the coast with Libyan rebels in pursuit in their first major victory since American and European airstrikes began a week ago.
articles.byline: By Kareem Fahim and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Note to Banks: It’s Not 2006 Anymore
articles.snippet: Attempts in Washington to return to the good old days for banks don’t look so good for taxpayers.
articles.abstract: Attempts in Washington to return to the good old days for banks don’t look so good for taxpayers.
articles.lead_paragraph: NOSTALGIA is running high on Wall Street for the days when junk mortgage underwriting and opaque derivatives trading juiced bank profits. As regulators continue to devise the machinery of the Dodd-Frank regulatory reform law, major financial institutions are working overtime in Washington to bring the good times back again.

articles.headline: AT&T Lobbyist Faces Beltway Test in T-Mobile Deal
articles.snippet: A merger would put AT&T into the No. 1 position among wireless providers, and its veteran lobbyist is on the case.
articles.abstract: A merger would put AT&T into the No. 1 position among wireless providers, and its veteran lobbyist is on the case.
articles.lead_paragraph: Washington

articles.headline: She Ended the Men’s Club of National Politics
articles.snippet: In 1984, Ms. Ferraro took her place in American history as the first woman nominated for national office by a major party.
articles.abstract: In 1984, Ms. Ferraro took her place in American history as the first woman nominated for national office by a major party.
articles.lead_paragraph: Geraldine A. Ferraro, the former Queens congresswoman who strode onto a podium in 1984 to accept the Democratic nomination for vice president and to take her place in American history as the first woman nominated for national office by a major party, died on Saturday in Boston. She was 75.

articles.headline: What Would Estée Do?
articles.snippet: Estée Lauder is expanding into new markets, all while keeping the heritage of the family matriarch in mind.
articles.abstract: Estée Lauder is expanding into new markets, all while keeping the heritage of the family matriarch in mind.
articles.lead_paragraph: HIGH above Fifth Avenue, near the southern fringe of Central Park, is a shrine to the fickle goddess Beauty.

articles.headline: Iowa May Turn G.O.P.’s Focus to Social Issues
articles.snippet: Iowans are pressing the likely Republican candidates on social and religious issues, overshadowing economic concerns.
articles.abstract: Iowans are pressing the likely Republican candidates on social and religious issues, overshadowing economic concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — The ailing economy and the Tea Party’s demand for smaller government have dominated Republican politics for two years, but a resurgent social conservative movement is shaping the first stage of the presidential nominating contest, complicating the strategy for candidates who prefer to focus on fiscal issues over faith.

articles.headline: Japanese Rules for Nuclear Plants Relied on Old Science
articles.snippet: For decades, Japanese officialdom and even parts of its engineering establishment clung to older scientific precepts for protecting nuclear plants.
articles.abstract: For decades, Japanese officialdom and even parts of its engineering establishment clung to older scientific precepts for protecting nuclear plants.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — In the country that gave the world the word tsunami, the Japanese nuclear establishment largely disregarded the potentially destructive force of the walls of water. The word did not even appear in government guidelines until 2006, decades after plants — including the Fukushima Daiichi facility that firefighters are still struggling to get under control — began dotting the Japanese coastline.
articles.byline: By Norimitsu Onishi and James Glanz

articles.headline: Unrest in Syria and Jordan Poses New Test for U.S. Policy
articles.snippet: Instability has spread to nations that the United States considers vital to its interests and to chances for peace in the Middle East.
articles.abstract: Instability has spread to nations that the United States considers vital to its interests and to chances for peace in the Middle East.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even as the Obama administration defends the NATO-led air war in Libya, the latest violent clashes in Syria and Jordan are raising new alarm among senior officials who view those countries, in the heartland of the Arab world, as far more vital to American interests.

articles.headline: A Girl’s Nude Photo, and Altered Lives
articles.snippet: Law enforcement officials and educators are struggling with how to confront minors who “sext.”
articles.abstract: Law enforcement officials and educators are struggling with how to confront minors who “sext.”
articles.lead_paragraph: LACEY, Wash. — One day last winter Margarite posed naked before her bathroom mirror, held up her cellphone and took a picture. Then she sent the full-length frontal photo to Isaiah, her new boyfriend.

articles.headline: Tainted Water at 2 Reactors Increases Alarm for Japanese
articles.snippet: High radiation levels were discovered in a flooded area inside the complex, raising new questions about how and when cleanup workers could resume their tasks.
articles.abstract: High radiation levels were discovered in a flooded area inside the complex, raising new questions about how and when cleanup workers could resume their tasks.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by  David Jolly,  Hiroko Tabuchi and  Keith Bradsher.
articles.byline: By David Jolly, Hiroko Tabuchi and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Libyan Rebels March Toward Qaddafi Stronghold
articles.snippet: There were unconfirmed reports early Monday that rebel forces had routed pro-government defenders in Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s tribal homeland of Surt.
articles.abstract: There were unconfirmed reports early Monday that rebel forces had routed pro-government defenders in Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s tribal homeland of Surt.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — American and European bombs battered Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s most important bastion of support in his tribal homeland of Surt on Sunday night, as rebels seeking his ouster capitalized on the damage from the Western airstrikes to erase their recent losses and return to the city’s doorstep.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Kareem Fahim

articles.headline: Long-Form Journalism Finds a Home
articles.snippet: The Atavist has captured new ways to present long-form content for the digital age, mixing multimedia presentations and deep, engrossing articles.
articles.abstract: The Atavist has captured new ways to present long-form content for the digital age, mixing multimedia presentations and deep, engrossing articles.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2009, Evan Ratliff, a freelance writer for Wired, and Nicholas Thompson, a senior editor there, had just concluded a particularly satisfying article in which Mr. Ratliff tried to drop off the grid for a month and obscure his whereabouts in the digital age, while Wired magazine offered $5,000 to the person who could find him.

articles.headline: Eminem Lawsuit May Raise Pay for Older Artists
articles.snippet: Many artists whose contracts predate digital music stand to profit significantly from a recent court decision.
articles.abstract: Many artists whose contracts predate digital music stand to profit significantly from a recent court decision.
articles.lead_paragraph: The most closely watched lawsuit in the music industry asks this question: how much should a song on iTunes or another digital music service be worth to the performer?

articles.headline: Russian Site Smokes Out Corruption
articles.snippet: Aleksei N. Navalny has attracted a vast audience with his Web site for investors even as he takes on state-owned companies in his crusade against corruption.
articles.abstract: Aleksei N. Navalny has attracted a vast audience with his Web site for investors even as he takes on state-owned companies in his crusade against corruption.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Before the Internet, a Russian dissident might have hoped to reach dozens of sympathetic readers with a mimeographed samizdat publication of forbidden material.

articles.headline: For $1,000, Site Lets Celebrities Say It Ain’t So
articles.snippet: A new Web site called ICorrect allows people who are unhappy about how they are portrayed on the Internet to set the record straight for $1,000 a year.
articles.abstract: A new Web site called ICorrect allows people who are unhappy about how they are portrayed on the Internet to set the record straight for $1,000 a year.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Imagine you are a well-known person aggrieved by how you are portrayed on the Internet: the slapdash Wikipedia entry; the unflattering gossip item; the endlessly repeated story about how you cheated on your spouse when in point of fact you were blamelessly resuscitating a platonic friend who was choking on an olive.

articles.headline: Hardly Settled in House, but Already in Hot Seat
articles.snippet: Freshman members of Congress, like Representative Bobby Schilling of Illinois, are already under pressure from all sides, Democrat and Republican.
articles.abstract: Freshman members of Congress, like Representative Bobby Schilling of Illinois, are already under pressure from all sides, Democrat and Republican.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOLINE, Ill. — In the 11 weeks since Representative Bobby Schilling left his family pizza business to join Congress, he has learned that sleeping on an office couch is extremely uncomfortable, that appearing on “Meet the Press” can be daunting, and that voting against federal money for a local rail project will cause some of your constituents to become very cranky.

articles.headline: Reality TV, Shaking Off Recession, Takes Entrepreneurial Turn
articles.snippet: If reality television could be considered an economic indicator, perhaps the recovery is under way. Two networks are betting on shows based on entrepreneurs competing for seed money.
articles.abstract: If reality television could be considered an economic indicator, perhaps the recovery is under way. Two networks are betting on shows based on entrepreneurs competing for seed money.
articles.lead_paragraph: If reality television could be considered an economic indicator, then perhaps the recovery is finally under way. Slowly.
